message: As we start 2017 and the 115th Congress, here's a brief look back on 2016:
Just two days into the 115th Congress, the feeling on Capitol Hill is different than it has been for the last eight years.
Congressman Jodey Arrington is the new representative for the congressional district just north of TX-11, which includes Lubbock and Abilene. Please join me in welcoming him to Congress!

Last night, the House of Representatives passed H.Res. 11, to Reject the Anti-Israel UN Resolution. Israel is our strongest ally in an increasingly unstable region, and to allow a resolution to pass the United Nations Security Council that states that Judaism’s holiest sites are an ‘occupied territory’ is absolutely unacceptable.   The United States has a long history of voting down anti-Israel resolutions at the United Nations Security Council- in fact, the United States has vetoed 42 anti-Israel resolutions since 1972. Unfortunately, President Obama and his Administration have chosen to ignore the special relationship between the United States and Israel, which is reprehensible. We must continue our nation’s long tradition of standing with Israel.

This week, I had the honor of being sworn in as a member of the 115th Congress. After taking the Oath of Office with my colleagues on the Floor of the House of Representatives, we each signed the oath and took some time to reflect on the incredible responsibility that this office bestows upon us.   The Oath of Office reads:  I, K. Michael Conaway, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which I am about to enter. So help me God.
Thank you to our nation's law enforcement officers who protect and serve our communities today and every day!

Today, the United States Senate begins confirmation hearings for President-elect Trump's cabinet nominations. Tune in right now to watch Senator Jeff Sessions's confirmation hearing for his nomination to Attorney General:
Thanks to all who joined me for my live teletown hall meeting tonight. Lots of great questions about Obamacare, and our plan to transition to a better healthcare system.

Next Tuesday, I will be holding two town hall meetings in the district. The first will be in Stanton, Texas at the Martin County-Library, and the second will be in Sterling City, Texas at the First National Bank. I hope you'll join me to discuss the issues that are on your mind!

Looking for the newest fishing hot spot in the 11th District? In a joint effort by the Lake Buchanan Conservation Corp. and Texas Parks and Wildlife, new fish attractors were placed in various places around Lake Buchanan this week. These structures create habitats that attract game fish such as Largemouth Bass and Crappie. I am always excited to see conservation efforts that not only strengthen our natural resources but provide for a great day on the water for anglers of all ages.

Today as my mother held the Bible, U.S. District Judge Robert Junell administered the oath of office during a local swearing-in ceremony. Even though I took the oath of office with my colleagues in DC at the start of this Congress, I think it's incredibly important to hold this ceremony in TX-11 because it is thanks to the people of this district that I have the honor of representing you in Congress.

Peeking out from the brush in Mason County, Spy Rock is considered the lesser known Enchanted Rock. Made of pink granite rock from the Precambrian Age, Spy Rock is accessible to all climbers, but the dome itself is on private property and not accessible. The closest town, Fredonia, Texas, was settled 3 miles away from Spy Rock and the locals used the outcropping as a marker when bringing their livestock and produce to town. Have you ever visited Spy Rock?
I really enjoyed visiting with The Midland Reporter-Telegram earlier this week to discuss the issues that President-elect Donald Trump will need to tackle starting day one.

Today, we are experiencing the cornerstone of our democracy: a peaceful transfer of power from one elected leader to the next. It is an honor to be in attendance at this historic event, to watch Donald J. Trump become the 45th President of the United States of America.   It would be a missed opportunity to not think about our awe-inspiring democracy on this day. Our democracy is the vehicle through which we have had the rights to freedom of speech, to bear arms, and to organize for over 240 years, but our democracy is only as good as its people. I am hopeful that this new Administration will help change the course of our nation for the better, keeping our democracy healthy for generations to come. We are truly blessed to live in this country.  Congratulations to President Donald J. Trump. I can’t wait to get our work started.

Great news out of the White House today- President Trump has signed executive actions clearing the way for approval of the Keystone XL Pipeline and the Dakota Access Pipeline. President Obama blocked both these projects and the jobs that they will create for years. I'm looking forward to working with President Trump to see these projects through and keep our economy working.
It's heartwarming to see the mark these West Texans left on DC while in town for the Inauguration.

A beautiful celebration of life at today's The March for Life- because every child deserves a chance at life. I am so proud that our nation's leaders attended the march today, including Vice President Pence and Kellyanne Conway.

Last Friday at the Republican retreat, Suzanne and I had the pleasure of hearing from Scott Smiley and his wife Tiffany. His is an incredible story, of a young man who graduated from West Point and was blinded while serving in Iraq. He kept his vision of becoming an Ironman, which he completed even after he was blinded. His message was of courage, faith and teamwork. What an incredible story of strength!

I am proud to have introduced the Veterans Second Amendment Protection Act, which will correct a bureaucratic failure that is currently preventing veterans who receive help navigating the VA from a fiduciary from exercising their constitutional right to bear arms. You can learn more about this bill from the NRA Institute for Legislative Action here:

Last night, the Llano, Tx Chamber of Commerce hosted the 93rd annual awards banquet, honoring citizens for their contributions to the community. Toby Fletcher, assistant principal at Llano High School, was named citizen of the year in recognition of all he has done for the children of Llano. Roland Rode was the Llano Hall of Fame recipient, honoring his hard work to better the community.   There were many other citizens honored, including Jerry and Alberta Allred as agriculture producer of the year, David Waters, Jil Dillard, Lori Gray, Karla Van Item, Mary Ellen Halamicck, and Sidone Thornton, as educators of the year. The men and women who serve Llano were also honored at this event. Congratulations to all the recipients of these awards- Llano thanks you for your service to the community!

Two years ago, Texas Governor Greg Abbott declared February 2nd to be Chris Kyle Day in Texas. Chris Kyle was a hero, who dedicated his life to protecting our country and helping others. It is also an important reminder that we should honor all our veterans and servicemembers for the sacrifices they have made to keep us free each and every day.

This week, over 44 high school seniors from TX-11 made their college plans official on National Signing Day. From Angelo State to Harvard and dozens of schools in between, these seniors and their families have a tremendous amount to be proud of. Do you know a student who's going to be a collegiate athlete come fall?

In Texas 11, our farming and ranching roots run deep. If you’re looking for something fun to do with friends and family, the San Angelo Stock Show and Rodeo is going on now through February 19th. Whether you’re cheering on students at the stock show, catching some PRCA action in the coliseum, or taking the kids to the petting zoo and carnival, there is a lot of fun to be had out at the San Angelo Coliseum and Fairgrounds!
Really great to have Commissioner Wayne Christian, of the Railroad Commission of Texas, at the Team Conaway staff retreat to talk about the future of the oil and gas industry in Texas.

The opportunity to be a part of a team, and learn from a man like Coach Mayfield, led me to be the man I am today. I am so grateful for the experiences I have had, and all the people I have met along the way.
Have you ever heard the remarkable love story of Texas Congressman Sam Johnson and his wife, Shirley? It's a great read for this #ValentinesDay.

Penwell, Texas was a typical West Texas oil town from the 1920s. It all started when J. H. Penn, a veteran West Texas Oil operator came in on the railway and drilled the discovery well of the Penwell-Jordan oilfield. On October 7, 1929, the area took off with the drilling of Penn’s well, the R. R. Penn Kloh-Rumsey No. 1. Because it was Penn’s oil well, the town became known as “Pennwell”.   The prospects started the same as any West Texas town that begun during the oil boom. By 1931 the town had nearly 3,000 residents, despite the town being only 2-3 years old. Although population statistics were hard to calculate due to migrant workers,  during the early 1930s the town had six lumberyards, several filling stations, multiple clothing stores, two hotels, a doctor's office, a drugstore, a barbershop, a pool hall, a coffee shop, a dance hall, and a paper, the Penwell News. However, like many oil towns when the work began to dwindle the population migrated to towns with more work. Today, the Joker Coffee Shop is one of the few things left standing. #WestTexas #OilTown

Do you have a neat story about Texas? The Bullock Texas State History Museum is collecting stories of family, history, and life in Texas for their Texas Story Project. You can submit one story or many, and there are prompts to help get you started. The museum has already begun featuring some stories on an interactive map, and #TX11 constituents have already begun participating. If you do decide to #ShareYourStory about our great state, post it here so we can all read it as well!

Yesterday, I joined Senator John Cornyn, U.S. Senator Dean Heller, Senator Thom Tillis, Rep. John Carter, and Rep. David Rouzer for a tour of the McAllen, Texas Border Patrol Station, Centralized Processing Center, and a boat tour of the Rio Grande River.  To start the day, we had the opportunity to speak with U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers about their experiences working at the border.  It's incredibly helpful to hear from the folks on the ground about what resources they need to successfully carry out their jobs, as well as the most vulnerable parts of the border.

This week, I visited a GE O&G facility in Odessa, Texas. This service center helps keep energy equipment running, which keeps our country going. I had the opportunity to not only tour the facility, but to also talk with about 50 employees for a town hall style meeting.
Had a wonderful time this week in Ballinger, Texas, delivering meals with Meals on Wheels America. Thanks to KTAB for capturing the day's events.

Are you a high school student interested in attending a Military Service Academy? Next Saturday, March 4th, my office will be holding Academy Day, an event for students to learn more about applying for a Service Academy, and what life is like at an Academy and beyond. This is a terrific opportunity for prospective students and their families to meet with Academy Liaison Officers and ROTC Representatives.  The event will be held on Saturday, March 4th, from 1:00 to 4:30 p.m. at Angelo State University, MCS Building, Room 100, 2200 Deana Drive in San Angelo. If you have any questions about attending the United States Naval Academy, West Point - The U.S. Military Academy, US Air Force Academy (Official), or United States Merchant Marine Academy, please come to #AcademyDay to learn more!

TX-19 Congressman Jodey Arrington and I had a terrific conversation with young agriculture producers in #Lubbock today. Afterwards, we called in to NewsTalk 710 KGNC AM to talk to James Hunt about all things #agriculture, including the 2018 farm bill.
A beautiful West Texas sunset tonight. I hope everyone had a wonderful Sunday with their loved ones. I was particularly blessed to spend this one with Suzanne.

At 11 AM CT, Chaplain Harvey H. Klee of Llano, Texas, will be leading Congress in prayer as the guest Chaplain for today. You'll be able to watch Chaplain Klee's invocation, as well as my remarks of appreciation on his behalf, live on C-SPAN or online at the link below:

Tomorrow, we will celebrate #TexasIndependenceDay. But did you know that in 1932, the Texas State Legislature passed a resolution to make this entire week Texas Week? Read the full story of #TexasWeek, from Texas Monthly, here:

Over the past eight years, EPA and the Army Corps of Engineers have repeatedly ignored the concerns of our nation’s farmers and ranchers in their quest to implement the #WOTUS rule. I applaud President Donald J. Trump for taking the first steps to dismantle this egregious example of regulatory overreach.
President Donald J. Trump is addressing a Joint Session of Congress with his vision for our country right now:

An incredibly touching moment from President Donald J. Trump's #JointAddress honoring Carryn Owens, the widow of a U.S. Navy Special Operator, Senior Chief William "Ryan" Owens. Ryan was a true hero to our nation, and as President Trump said last night, Ryan's legacy is etched into eternity.

Earlier this week, The American Legion National Headquarters Chaplain Harvey Klee gave the opening prayer for the House of Representatives. Chaplain Klee is a constituent of #TX11, and after he gave the invocation I had the opportunity to show him around the Capitol building. Speaker Paul Ryan and House Chaplain Patrick Conroy even made guest appearances to say hello!
Happy Texas Independence Day! It's a great day to be a Texan as we celebrate all of the many things that make Texas the extraordinary state that it is. #TexasIndependenceDay

This weekend, my office hosted Academy Day, which we organize annually to educate young men and women about the United States military service academies and the process students must go through to apply for admission.  Our nation's service academies are some of the finest institutions of education in the nation, and I appreciate representatives from the academies coming to West Texas to share this information.

Today, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce and Committee on Ways and Means passed the American Health Care Act, the Republican solution for a new health care system. This is the first step towards this legislation passing the House of Representatives.  My colleague Rep. Kevin Brady, fellow Texan and Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee wrote the following column for USA TODAY to detail what this plan will mean for you. Unlike Obamacare, you don't have to wait until it becomes law to read it- it's already posted for anyone to read at ReadTheBill.GOP.

I'll be joining Craig Anderson on #KWEL LIVE in 5 minutes to discuss what's been happening in DC this week, including the new Republican health care plan. Tune in to AM 1070 or FM 107.1 if you're in the Midland, Texas area, or listen live online here:
The devestating Texas Panhandle wildfires have already claimed four lives and destroyed hundreds of thousands of acres of land. One Midland rancher is going above and beyond to help:

Not too long ago, I mentioned the Bullock Texas State History Museum's #TexasStoryProject. The Texas Story Project is an interactive way to explore Texas history, and participate in Texas History by sharing your story. This story, about The Baker Hotel, Mineral Wells Texas, was submitted by Kevin Pruitt, a Mineral Wells, Texas native, complete with a video that delves into the history of this grand hotel.

Today, I spoke on the House Floor during debate on the Veterans 2nd Amendment Protection Act. This important bill prevents the inaccurate labeling of certain veterans, which automatically puts them on the FBI's NICS list. As I argued during the debate, the determination to label a veteran as "mentally defective" should be made by the courts, not government bureaucrats. Just a few minutes ago, I cast my vote in favor of this legislation, and I'm pleased to report that it passed the House of Representatives 240-175.

This morning, the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence is hearing from FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation Director Comey and NSA - National Security Agency Director Rogers in an open hearing. As most Intelligence Committee hearings are classified, this is a rare opportunity to get a glimpse into the issues that members of the Intelligence Committee, including myself, see every day. You can watch the hearing live online here:

Later today, I'll be holding a #TX11 Facebook Live Town Hall on the American Health Care Act, the Republican plan to repeal Obamacare and repair the health care system. If you have a question you'd like me to answer, please leave it in the comment section and tune back in to this page at 4:15 PM CT to participate in the town hall.
Join me right now for a Facebook live town hall on the American Health Care Act

This afternoon, U.S. Army Captain Luis Avila and his wife, Claudia Avila, stopped by my office to say hello and share their story. Luis joined the Army in 2000, became an officer in 2004, and served five combat tours in Iraq and Afghanistan. While leading his team on December 27, 2011, an IED detonated nearby. Three soldiers were killed by the blast, and two others were severely wounded. Luis suffered two strokes, two heart attacks, amputation of his left leg, and a severe head injury that stopped oxygen from getting to his brain. He went into a very long coma, and the doctors pulled Claudia aside and told her that he was not going to make it. She told them, "you gotta have faith." A month later, Luis opened his eyes for the first time.   Last November, Luis, Claudia, and their three sons moved into a new smart home, thanks to the Gary Sinise Foundation. The home has many features that allow Luis to be independent, like automatic opening doors, wide pathways, and an elevator. It's also close to Walter Reed Medical Center, where Luis is continuing his therapies.   Luis and Claudia, you are extraordinary examples of faith, love, and sacrifice. Thank you both for sharing your story with me, and for your tremendous service to our country.

Every year, I play in The Congressional Baseball Game for Charity and wear the uniform of a team from the 11th District of Texas.  This year I am honored to suit up in a Yellow Jacket uniform from Howard Payne University in Brownwood!  I want to thank HPU President Bill Ellis, Howard Payne University Athletics Athletic Director Hunter Sims, Head Coach Stephen Lynn, and the entire team for presenting the uniform to me between doubleheader games this weekend.  Speaking of, congratulation Howard Payne for sweeping LeTourneau!

This Thursday from 12-4 PM, UTPB - The University of Texas of the Permian Basin is hosting a job fair for students and alumni. Dozens of companies have already signed up- if you're looking for a job, get your resume ready!
Thanks to the 10,000+ constituents who joined me for a productive teletown hall last night. To sign up for future teletown halls, please visit conaway.house.gov.

Last night, I spoke on the House Floor to bring awareness to the religious persecutions of Christians by the Chinese government. Pastor John, who has dedicated his life to spreading the word of Jesus Christ, was arrested and detained while crossing the border between Myanmar and China on his small motorcycle which was loaded with food and medicine. He has crossed the border in this fashion for years without incident, and I believe the inflated charges in this instance are due to the fact that he is a Christian. I have asked the State Department to assist in this case, to stop the aggressive religious persecution of Christians in China.  #FreedomforPastorJohn

Congratulations to the Granbury Rifle Team for their excellent performance at the CMP Regional Championships! The Granbury Team One place 2nd and the Granbury Team Two placed 6th among precision teams, which qualified them to compete at Nationals in June.   Granbury High School was represented by Kayla Hitshew, Trinity Hathaway, Clarissa Layland, Brittney Pinckard, Elizabeth Plecity, Tamara Peters, Allison Henry and Makenize Sheffield. Great job, and good luck at Nationals!

Today, Judge Neil Gorsuch was confirmed to the Supreme Court of the United States of America. Judge Gorsuch is a truly terrific legal mind, with a strong history of defending the Constitution. President Donald J. Trump made a promise during his campaign that he would select a nominee for the Supreme Court to follow the example led by the late Justice Antonin Scalia, and his nomination of Judge Gorsuch proved just that. Congratulations to Judge Gorsuch on this incredible honor. #scotus

Today I met with some really bright high school students who sit on my Congressional Youth Advisory Council. We heard from two U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents, and then had a discussion about our immigration system and what changes could be made to our country's immigration policy. These conversations are not easy, but it's great to see these future leaders getting involved in the process.

Thanks to all who have made the trek out to one of my town halls this week in Mertzon, Texas, Llano, Texas, Brownwood, Texas, and Dublin, Texas. We haven't always agreed on every issue, but we've had some really terrific conversations as a result and I am continually impressed by the way in which #TX11 constituents are able to express their opinions in a way that is respectful to one another. I appreciate everyone taking the time out of their day to participate and have your voice heard!

The Easter season is a joyous occasion, where we celebrate the sacrifices made by one individual for the greater good. Jesus Christ sacrificed himself for our salvation, and for that we take this opportunity to honor him and reflect on those who are following his lead.  Everyday, American men and women continue the tradition by donning the colors of our nation and putting their lives on the line in order to keep us safe. These servicemembers and their families give up spending holidays, birthdays, and major life events together.  To all those who have served and sacrificed for the greater good, thank you. And from my family to yours, Happy Easter.

This week is the last chance for high school students to submit their artwork to the #TX11 2017 Congressional Art Competition. This is an incredible chance for students to have their artwork displayed alongside pieces from around the country in the United States Capitol. For more information, including information on submissions, please visit the website here:

I recently had the pleasure of visiting Goodfellow AFB - 17th Training Wing with Senator John Cornyn. Goodfellow's work in intelligence and cyber security is especially critical to our nation's safety. I am incredibly proud to represent this terrific community of servicemembers.

Today is the last chance for #TX11 high school students to submit their artwork for the 2017 Congressional Art Competition! In order to have your piece considered, please submit it to one of the six district offices by the end of the day. All artwork will be displayed, and the winner will be selected and announced at a reception for all participants at Angelo State University on May 6th.   The winner will receive airfare for themselves and a parent to Washington, DC to attend the unveiling ceremony in June, where they will have the opportunity to see their artwork displayed in the U.S. Capitol! #CongressionalArtCompetition

This week, I had the privilege of presenting a certificate recognizing Shane Smiskol of Granbury, Texas as the winner of #TX11's first Congressional App Challenge in 2016.  The 2017 Challenge will take place from July 26 - Nov 1. High school aged students can work individually or to groups of up to four students to develop an app on any topic. More information can be found here:   #CongressionalAppChallenge

In May of 1847, a young German immigrant leader and a powerful Comanche chief signed a mutual defense pact that is believed to be the only unbroken peace treaty between American Indians and U.S. settlers. The German immigrant society had purchased the Fisher-Miller grant, of 3.88 million acres. However, the Comanche had already claimed that area as their hunting grounds. It became the responsibility of John Meusebach, the 33-year-old commissioner-general of the immigrant group, to make peace with the Comanche.   In January, Chief Ketemoczy of the Penetaka Comanche met Meusebach, who explained the immigrants' friendly intentions. Chief Ketemoczy was receptive, and promised to summon the chiefs of the western bands of Comanche to a peace council on the San Saba River.   When the talks concluded with a peace pipe and an agreement, the treaty allowed the colonists to travel freely between the Llano and San Saba rivers. The Comanche could also come into the settlers' towns without fear, and would receive the colonists' support against their enemies.   This was a unique treaty, because the government had no part in it. There were a few infringements over time, but the treaty held the test of time.
Good news this afternoon for President Bush and his family. Praying for a continued speedy recovery for this American hero.
Congratulations to Evan Thomas, my District Director, for being honored as part of the Odessa Under 40 Class of 2017!

This morning I met with U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt, where we discussed the many environmental regulations harming economic growth in Texas. There is work to be done, but I am happy to report that U.S. EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt is committed to addressing the concerns of rural America.

On Saturday, I had the pleasure of hosting the 2017 Congressional Art Competition for the 11th District of Texas.  We had 32 students enter the competition from around the district, and I appreciate the students that came to Angelo State University for the presentations of certificates and awards and reception.  Kristen Power of Lee High School in Midland was named the winner of the Art Competition, and her piece will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol for the next year with the other winning pieces from all over the country. Her piece is titled "Molting of Me".  Thank you, President Brian May, and ASU for providing the West Texas Collections Gallery as the venue, and I appreciate members of art department serving as judges.
Suzanne is my rock, and I consider myself lucky everyday that I get to call myself her husband. Congratulations, Suzanne. Thank you for all that you do for me and our family.
This week, I got to take part in the groundbreaking ceremony for the new Midland Convention Center. CBS7 News / KOSA-TV was there to capture the event:

Today, the ROTC detachment at Angelo State University commissioned 6 cadets as 2nd Lieutenants into the United States Air Force. Congratulations to these 6 outstanding young men:  2nd Lt Peter Lennarson - Cyberspace Officer 2nd Lt Matthew Eddins - RPA Pilot  2nd Lt Todd Duquette - Intelligence Officer 2nd Lt Raul Reyes - Logistics Readiness Officer 2nd Lt Jake Jackson - Aircraft Maintenance Officer 2nd Lt Benjamin Carney - Logistics Readiness Officer
Happy Mother's Day to all the terrific moms of #TX11!
Please join me in wishing my beautiful, kind, intelligent wife Suzanne a very happy birthday!

The Stephenville Historical House Museum in Stephenville, Texas, offers a unique opportunity to explore Stephenville’s history. Located in the “Cowboy Capitol of the World,” the museum boasts 12 structures from the 19th Century. The campus spans 3 acres near the Bosque River, and each building contains period furnishings and artifacts. Visit a beautifully preserved schoolhouse, a 2-story Victorian House, a chapel and more! Self-guided and guided tours are available during office hours, 10-5pm Tuesdays through Saturdays, and 1-5pm on Sundays. The free museum is funded by donations, it is a great way to re-live the unique heritage of the Cross Timbers region.
This #PoliceWeek, don't forget to thank an officer for all that they do to keep our communities safe
Great to see #TX11 represented on the list of the top 50 barbecue joints in Texas with Cooper's Old Time Pit Bar-B-Que. What's your favorite spot on the list?

I am really lucky to have Suzanne in DC this week for many reasons, none the least of which was her help as a guest chef for the March of Dimes event last night.  President Roosevelt's personal struggle with polio led him to found March of Dimes, with the mission of preventing birth defects and infant mortality. This organization has worked tirelessly to help keep babies healthy and happy. Thanks to March of Dimes for letting us be a part of the fight!

I am proud of these two fine young men, and the five others from #TX11, for their dedication to serving our country. Gregory and Alexander, good luck as you begin your next chapters at the United States Naval Academy and West Point - The U.S. Military Academy.   We have five more outstanding students- Stephanie Choe, Kaleb Nunez, Caelynn Ferguson, Judith Horton, and Kasey Ludwig- who are all headed to the US Air Force Academy (Official).   #MilitaryAcademies #Service
#TBT to 26 years ago today. Happy anniversary, my beautiful bride.

In the 1860s, Texas Ranger Charles Goodnight and pioneer cowboy Oliver Loving took notice of an inadequate supply of beef in New Mexico and parts of Texas. Poor planning caused many soldiers at Ft. Sumner to go to bed hungry, so the two men packed their bags. They took their cattle and headed north, as far Wyoming. This historic journey would create the Goodnight-Loving Trail.   The trail began along the Concho River near the Fort in the area and is often regarded as the most historic cattle trail in the west. The prevalence of the trail led to many settlers moving towards Ft. Concho, and this migration would help begin what is now San Angelo. This story is just another example of the important role that the region has played in not only Texas but America. Charles Goodnight and Oliver Loving were truly pioneers of their time and we are all better today for them.

The Coleman PCRA Rodeo began in 1936 as a way for locals from Coleman to celebrate the Texas Centennial.  It was such a hit they made it an annual celebration! Initially, the rodeo was held at the Coleman High School Football field, but by 1947, the Coleman Rodeo Association decided it was time to create a real rodeo facility. It grew over time, and today the area features a livestock show barn, perimeter fence, pecan trees, an outdoor dance pavilion, and a horse barn. In an era where we are surrounded by technology, the Annual Coleman Rodeo remains committed to the original traditions of the Texas Rodeo.   This summer, the Rodeo will be held June 8-10, and in addition to the rodeo, it features live music from Sam Riggs, William Clark Green, the Kevin Seale Band, and Koe Wetzel. Advance Rodeo Tickets are $8 for adults and $10 for children. A 3 time nominee for the Rodeo of the Year Honors, the Coleman Rodeo is a great weekend getaway.

When you think of West Texas, you might think of wind; but did you know that there was once a “Windy City” in West Texas? The site of Chicago was established on the Bartow Ranch by W.C. Bishop – a Chicago, Illinois, native. In just a few short years, another community formed down the road. The Chicago post office was moved and Chicago’s name was changed to Stemmons after Walter Stemmons took over the roles of Bartow ranch foreman and postmaster. Years later, Stemmons and Lamesa came into competition for the Dawson county seat. An election took place, and with just five more votes, Lamesa became the official county seat. Today, the town of Chicago no longer exists, but is remembered by a historical marker and a Lamesa street named after the town.

Memorial Day is a day to honor the many men and women who gave the greatest sacrifice they could for our nation. Last week, Congressman Brian Mast spoke on the House floor about what Memorial Day means to him- and it's worth taking a few moments today to listen in and reflect on the incredible significance of the day. Brian, it is an honor to serve with you in Congress.

It was an honor to join in the Memorial Day Exercises at historic Fort Concho in San Angelo this morning to remember our fallen servicemen and servicewomen who gave their lives to protect our republic.
Thanks to everyone who came out to one of my three town halls this week in Junction, Texas, Goldthwaite, Texas, and Coleman, Texas. Hope to see you soon at a #TX11 town hall near you!

We visited the San Saba County Courthouse yesterday morning while in San Saba, Texas. Over the last few months, they've gutted it, in order to restore it to its historic look circa early 1900s (approx. 1911). This has been a dream of the community for nearly 20 years.  I look forward to coming back when the renovations are completed next year. #TX11

Have you been to the Ben Hogan Museum in Dublin, Texas? If you're a golf fan, take the chance to stop by the museum next time you're in Dublin- it's on the Travel Channel's bucket list as a can't miss!

On this day, in 1944, thousands of Allied troops poured onto the beaches of Normandy, France in one of the most significant military operations in human history. These forces faced a stretch of 200 yards of open sand before any sort of cover from the relentless machine fire and artillery. While they fought their way across the beaches and up the cliffs beyond, thousands of paratroopers that had jumped into the area in the pre-dawn hours battled to destroy German defenses and to secure the roads and bridges that the Nazis could use to reinforce their troops and repel the invasion. The fighting was gruesome and ceaseless, but by the end of the day, Allied forces had their foothold in Europe. Hitler’s “Sea Wall” had been breached.  The D-Day operation was described by Winston Churchill as, “undoubtedly the most complicated and difficult that has ever been endured.” The success of the landings came at a heavy price: over 10,000 Allied casualties. The sacrifice and courage of these men and others beside them gave the Allies the position that they needed to begin the push into Nazi Europe. We will always be indebted to those who have fought and continue to fight for our freedom, and seventy-three years later, we remember the men of Operation Overlord.  “Strengthened by their courage, heartened by their valor, and borne by their memory, let us continue to stand for the ideals for which they lived and died.” – Ronald Reagan, 1984

Risien Park in San Saba, Texas was donated by E. Guy Risien and the Lower Colorado River Authority to create a beautiful park space. There are RV hookups, and places to grill and picnic. This park is unique, because to get to the beautiful Pecan Grove Nestled in the Park, you enter through an old railroad trestle. Throughout the park, trail maps and historical markers help history come to life! Beside Risien Park, the San Saba River Nature Park features two miles of walkways, and space to fish and go birdwatching. If you live in San Saba, it’d be a great place for an afternoon visit, and if you’re travelling from further, it can be the perfect base from which to explore San Saba County.

When Fort McKavett was first established in 1852, it served as a refuge for settlers being hounded by Indians. Today it is considered one of the best preserved military outposts in Texas. The post was abandoned in 1859, but was later reopened in 1868 due to a reemergence of Comanche Indian hostility after the Civil War. During this time period, the compound also housed a number of Buffalo Soldiers. Fort McKavett was completely abandoned in 1883. If you were to visit Fort McKavett State Historic Site today, you would find a number of restored buildings and the remnants of the commanding officer’s headquarters that burned in 1941. Though the site is remembered for its historical significance, it is also appreciated for its beautiful landscape and abundance of wildflowers.

This morning, a gunman opened fire at the GOP's 2017 Congressional Baseball Game for Charity practice. I am unharmed, but others, including Majority Whip Scalise, were shot. Please keep them in your prayers today.

I have played in The Congressional Baseball Game for Charity every year since I came to Congress, and it has become one of my favorite traditions. The camaraderie we feel as players transcends party, as we live out our childhood dreams of playing on a major league field.   Tonight, the game will go on. We will play the game we love in honor of Congressman Steve Scalise, Matt Mika, Zach Barth, Special Agent Crystal Griner, and Special Agent David Bailey. We will remain thankful for the heroic actions of Special Agents Griner and Bailey, as well as the other officers who arrived to our aid quickly, without whom the events of yesterday might have turned drastically worse.   Tonight, we will stand together on the field, united in our love for this country.   It's time to play ball.

Fort Phantom Hill Historic Site is located just outside #TX11 in Abilene, TX,  and is a part of the Texas Forts Trail, a 650 mile highway tour of historic Texas forts. This fort was built to protect the frontier in the early 1850’s as expansion occurred. It was occupied by the U.S. Army from 1851 to 1854. Shortly after, a fire destroyed the thatched roofs and log walls, wrecking many of the buildings. But today, lots still remains to be explored. There are 3 original stone buildings, a guardhouse, warehouse, and powder magazine. In addition, there are many stone chimneys and foundations. To see the entire Fort only takes about 30 minutes and admission is free. This is one of the best ways to celebrate local history if you’re passing through the area, or if you’re looking for a quick way to get the kids outside and exploring.

With #HurricaneHarvey headed towards Texas, please take every precaution to stay safe over the next few days. FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency has released these safety tips to prepare yourself:   FEMA recommends visitors and residents in areas potentially affected by Hurricane Harvey take the following actions: If the storm is expected to affect your area, know your evacuation zone and follow the direction of state, local or tribal officials if an evacuation is ordered for your area. Storm surge poses a significant threat for drowning and can sometimes cut off evacuation routes, so do not delay leaving if an evacuation is ordered for your area.  Monitor local radio or TV stations for updated emergency information, and follow the instructions of state, local, and tribal officials.  There is the potential for flooding and storm surge with Hurricane Harvey. Driving through a flooded area can be extremely hazardous. Nearly half of all flash flood deaths happen in vehicles. Stay safe when in your car by watching for flooding in low lying areas, at bridges and highway dips. As little as six inches of water may cause you to lose control of your vehicle. If you encounter floodwaters, remember – turn around, don’t drown.

If you are looking for ways to help those impacted by #HurricaneHarvey, this list is a great place to start.   If you are in an impacted area, remember that this is still a dangerous storm. If you come across a flooded area, it's always better to turn around.   Only call 911 if you have an immediate need for medical attention or evacuation assistance. If you can't get through to 911 on first try, keep calling.  Another option is to place a call to one of five numbers for the Houston Command Center of the United States Coast Guard. The numbers are:  281-464-4851 281-464-4852 281-464-4853 281-464-4854 282-464-4855

If you are near Brownwood, Texas and looking for a way to help those affected by #HurricaneHarvey, the Howard Payne University Baseball team is hosting donation drive on Saturday.   If there is a donation drive or fundraiser in your area, please share the details in the comments below.

Are you looking for ways to help with #HurricaneHarvey relief efforts?  To volunteer with high water vehicles or boats: Call 713-881-3100 and ask for a Fire Marshal   Medical personnel can contact Remote Area Medical to help with rescue efforts:  Contact RAM at volunteers@ramusa.org or 865-579-1530.   Anyone wanting to be paid for their services:  http://www.fema.gov/about-industry-liaison-program    For contractors looking for work, they should be directed to the State of Texas purchasing and contracting office: 512-463-3034, option 1.   Independent drivers/haulers: Coyote Broker https://www.coyote.com/ 877-6-COYOTE   877-626-9683   Group drivers/haulers: www.GSA.gov 1-844-GSA-4111   (1-844-472-4111)

16 years ago today, our nation changed forever. On September 11, 2001, terror struck the World Trade Center and the hearts of the world. We mourned the innocent lives taken in this attack, supported the first responders who risked their lives, and called upon brave men and women in our Armed forces to defend our freedom. From this tragedy, we grew stronger. We are a nation that cannot be torn down by radical terrorists no matter the threat they pose. We continue to fight against all terrorism and stand together as Americans, prepared to protect liberty for all. May we never forget the sacrifices made daily for our freedoms. #NeverForget

Thank you Faith2Action for recognizing our legislative efforts to save the unborn through the Heartbeat Bill Hero Award. Later today, the House will be voting on the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act to prevent abortions after 20 weeks. Science has proven that at 20 weeks, a baby in utero can feel pain. I'm proud to stand with my colleagues in support of this legislation.

There is no life more vulnerable than the life of an unborn child.  Medical professionals have reached a consensus that at 20 weeks, a child in utero can feel pain and physical suffering.   The legislation we passed today, which I was proud to cosponsor, ensures that no child capable of feeling pain will be subjected to the cruelty of an abortion.

I am proud to introduce the 2017 Angels in Adoption for the 11th District of Texas. The Congressional Coalition on Adoption Institute does a terrific job recognizing those who have gone above and beyond advocating for adoption, and the Young family from Odessa is a shining example. Tara and Roger Young’s three beautiful children are a true testament to their family’s inspiring story of love, patience, and miracles.

Congressman Steve Scalise, Senator Jeff Flake, Brad Wenstrup and I sat down with Martha MacCallum this week to talk about the morning a gunman opened fire at our baseball practice.   Tune in to The Story with Martha MacCallum tonight as we reflect on what happened that morning, and how glad we are to have Steve back in action.

As a legislator—but more importantly as a father and grandfather—I am seriously concerned about the mountain of debt our nation is passing on to our children and grandchildren. Later today, the House will vote on a budget for FY18 that will balance our budget in 10 years—something House Republicans have been trying to accomplish for a long time. It's up to us to clean up this mess before our children and grandchildren have to pay the price for years of this nation's fiscal irresponsibility.

ICYMI: Back in June, we were at our last practice for the Congressional Baseball Game for Charity when a gunman opened fire at us, hitting five individuals- including Majority Whip Congressman Steve Scalise. We were incredibly fortunate that two Capitol Police officers were there that morning, and prevented that horrific morning from becoming worse.   This week, Senator Jeff Flake, Congressman Brad Wenstrup, and I sat down with Fox News to welcome Steve back to Congress. Steve, we’re all so glad to have you back in action.

The Republican vision for tax reform supports the American workers and families who have been shouldering the burdens of the recession for too long. Small businesses have been held back, unable to grow and create jobs under the current burdensome tax code. Tax reform changes that, putting Main Street back in the driver’s seat. In fact, the average American family will see an extra $4,000 back in their pockets each year.  Modernizing our tax code in the face of globalization puts the needs of our nation, our businesses, and our families first. And that’s a plan for America we can all support. The 5 police officers that intervened during the shooting at our baseball practice in June saved countless lives. I am eternally grateful for their presence that morning. Those officers were awarded the Capitol Police Medal of Honor this morning, and will forever be remembered as heroes.   https://www.c-span.org/video/?437064-1/us-capitol-police-officers-awarded-medal-honor
Tomorrow is #VeteransDay. We should honor the men and women who have served this great nation of sacrificed their life defending our freedoms everyday.
Suzanne and I would like to wish all who have served our great nation a Happy Veterans Day! Your service and sacrifice is priceless.
There’s no place like the 50 yard line. Thank you UTPB Athletics and Angelo State University for letting me officiate the coin flip at this weekend’s game. Suzanne and I loved watching the game!

Tomorrow at 4 PM I will be hosting a Tax Reform Facebook LIVE Town Hall. Leave your questions in the comment section below and I'll do my best to answer those concerns during the broadcast. Stay tuned!  UPDATE: I'm still on the floor voting, so we'll be getting started in the next 20 minutes.
Join me now for a live discussion on tax reform. Ask your tax reform questions in the comment section below.

Our nation’s constitution was written with the understanding that we as Americans would continue to be a religious and moral people. To recognize #NationalBibleWeek, I took a moment to address why we must take it upon ourselves to maintain a moral high ground.
I have two #TX11 town halls coming up before Thanksgiving! Don’t miss your chance to come and join the conversation!
NA
Today, the House of Representatives passed the most sweeping tax reform legislation this country has seen in over 30 years- an accomplishment I am proud to stand behind.
Thank you Jonell Inc. Filter Products for the tour and walk through of how your company is sustaining momentum in American manufacturing and building opportunities for jobs in Breckenridge, Texas.
Fantastic town hall in Granbury, Texas! I am thankful for constituents who take the time to come out and share their comments and concerns.
We have countless blessings to be thankful for each year. Suzanne and I would like to wish everyone a Happy Thanksgiving!

This week I got the chance to speak with a few seniors at Midland Classical Academy and answer questions about net neutrality, tax reform, and healthcare. These students are exposed to countless influences on legislative topics and I was impressed with their willingness to participate in these conversations!

#GivingTuesday is a great reminder to keep others at the heart of the Christmas season.  Earlier this year I had the opportunity to deliver with @MealsonWheels! Service is a gift that truly is priceless.

#TaxReform is a victory for our economy, it’s the right thing to do, and yes, by the way, I think it will help Republicans with the 2018 election.   https://twitter.com/sbgc2c/status/935998671002505217

Christmas came a little early this year for my sons. Each of them have been colorblind their entire lives, mainly without the color green. This year, my boys got to experience Thanksgiving in FULL color through color blind corrective glasses! Their reactions are priceless.
Join me at the Garden City Community Center this afternoon for a Town Hall meeting!

One step closer to tax reform. This legislation, which is the largest overhaul of the tax code in over 30 years, will deliver tax cuts to low- and middle-income families across Texas. It will make the American economy competitive globally, and help grow American businesses to create more jobs here at home, not overseas. I’m looking forward to conferencing with the Senate and getting these tax cuts to the President’s desk.   https://www.google.com/amp/www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/12/02/senate-oks-sweeping-tax-reform-bill-trump-predicts-final-passage-before-christmas.amp.html

Thank you Texas Farm Bureau for continuing to support the men and women who feed and clothe this great nation. I am humbled to have been recognized this past weekend, and grateful for the farmer who truly harvests the meaning of service and work ethic.

The results are in! Congratulations to Ethan Thames of Midland Premier School, who has been chosen as The Congressional App Challenge winner. Ethan created an application that helps beginner Python 3 programmers format code- a very advanced concept! Way to go!

On December 7, 1941, countless lives were lost in a horrifying attack on our United States Navy. We will always remember this day, as President Franklin D. Roosevelt declared, “in infamy.” #PearlHarbor76

The Farm Bill helps farmers and producers feed and clothe America. The House Agriculture Committee is now hard at work on the #FarmBill2018  https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=2&v=j9K35Sw15Qs

Congressman Gene Green and I introduced legislation opposing any new taxes or fees for music played on local radio stations earlier this year. Today, a majority of the House of Representatives chose to support radio stations across this nation that provide rural areas communication infrastructure that can save lives.

I do my best to keep in touch with the 11th district when I’m in DC through telephone or Facebook Live town halls, but there's something about town halls face to face that make me love my job more each time I get a chance to visit with #TX11  If you'd like to know when I'll be in town, sign up for email updates below:  www.conaway.house.gov
Congratulations to my alma mater, Texas A&M University-Commerce on their National Championship Title! Go Lions!

Countless men and women will be sacrificing time away from family and loved ones this Christmas while protecting our freedoms and serving our country. Suzanne and I are forever grateful for our troops’ service.

As we come to the end of 2017, I look back and stand amazed at how fortunate I am to represent the 11th district of Texas.   We can calculate the miles traveled, days in Washington, D.C., and votes cast, but the passion for my district cannot be measured. I am thankful for my responsibilities with the House Agriculture Committee , House Armed Services Committee Republicans, and calling to the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. Let's look forward to a new year!

Congratulations to Stephenville Yellow Jacket Football's senior offensive lineman, Ty’von Anderson-Robision, who earned a spot on The Associated Press Sports Editor’s All-State Football Team for Conference 4A. Way to go!   http://theflashtoday.com/2017/12/19/jackets-earn-4a-all-state-acclaim-from-associated-press/
The path between #tx11 and Washington D. C. is one I know all too well. Looking at the mileage roundup for 2017, it seems out of this world!
“Glory to God in the highest and on earth peace, good will toward men,” — Luke 2:14   Suzanne and I would like to wish everyone a Merry Christmas! May we all remember the reason for the season.
There’s truly no place like home. As I reflect on my time in the district in 2017, it sure doesn’t feel like 10,000 miles! Wow!

It has been 5 years since the tragic accident during Midland’s Show of Support/Hunt for Heroes parade celebration.  Today, our community dedicated Heroes Plaza in remembrance of the four veterans that lost their lives.  I was so proud of how our community came together following the accident, and I remain proud that we continue to honor the men that lost their lives and the families that were impacted.

This week, Congress passed a historic tax cuts package. Not only will families across the country see their tax burdens lowered in the new year, but corporations have already responded by increasing their minimum wages and handing out bonuses to non-management employees. Looking forward to President Trump signing this bill into law!
